I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Facilitation of the cross-border movement of goods, vehicles, and people between and 
among the countries of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) is a priority initiative under the 
GMS  economic  cooperation  program.  It  supports  the  GMS  program’s  strategic  thrusts  of 
enhancing  connectivity,  promoting  competitiveness,  and  engendering  a  greater  sense  of 
community. Cross-border transport facilitation enhances connectivity by maximizing the benefits 
derived from subregional transport infrastructure in terms of increased trade and investment. 
Improved efficiency resulting from the easier flow of goods and people across borders promotes 
the competitiveness of participating countries, individually and as a subregion. A greater sense 
of  community  is  fostered  directly  through  the  harmonization  of  rules  and  procedures,  and 
increased interaction between and among the peoples of the subregion.   
2.  At the Second GMS Summit held in Kunming, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), in 
July 2005, the GMS leaders were “encouraged by the considerable progress in negotiating the 
annexes  and  protocols  of  the  Cross-Border  Transport  Agreement  (CBTA)  and  the 
commencement of its implementation.” They further reaffirmed their commitment “to move with 
speed and purpose to implement the Agreement at an increasing number of border crossings.” 
The proposed technical assistance (TA) has been requested by the GMS countries to support 
their  efforts  to  facilitate  cross-border  transport  and  trade  in  the  subregion  through  the 
accelerated implementation of the CBTA at key border crossings. The TA will complement the 
GMS Strategic Framework for Action on Trade Facilitation and Investment, which will enhance 
the benefits of the CBTA through a comprehensive set of measures to facilitate trade. Fact-
finding for the TA was conducted in September 2005. The TA design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.1 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The CBTA is a comprehensive multilateral instrument that covers relevant aspects of 
cross-border transport and trade facilitation, including (i) single-stop/single-window inspection, 
(ii) cross-border movement of persons, (iii) transit traffic, (iv) arrangements to enable transport 
operators  to  undertake  cross-border  transport,  and  (v)  exchange  of  traffic  rights  between 
countries. Assisted by ADB2, the CBTA was formulated, signed, and ratified by all six GMS 
governments, and 16 of its 20 implementing annexes and protocols3 have also been signed to 
date.   
4.  Implementation of the CBTA is expected to mitigate key nonphysical barriers to the 
efficient  cross-border movement  of  goods,  vehicles,  and  people in  the  GMS.  The  barriers 
include (i) restrictions on the entry of motor vehicles, which result in costly and time-consuming 
transshipment; (ii) inconsistent and difficult border crossing formalities and procedures related to

processing of goods, vehicles, and people at border checkpoints. The CBTA implementation is 
an  integral  component  in  the  transformation  of  the  GMS  road  corridors  into  full-fledged 
economic corridors.  
5.  Memoranda of understanding (MOUs) for CBTA implementation have been finalized for 
7 of the 15 key border crossings in the GMS covered by the CBTA. These are the Dansavanh 
(Lao People’s Democratic Republic [Lao PDR])-Lao Bao (Viet Nam), Mukdahan (Thailand)-
Savannakhet (Lao PDR), and Mae Sot (Thailand)-Myawaddy (Myanmar) border crossings along 
the  East-West  Economic  Corridor;  the  Bavet  (Cambodia)-Moc  Bai  (Viet  Nam)  and 
Aranyaprathet (Thailand)-Poipet (Cambodia) border crossings along the Southern Economic 
Corridor; and the Mae Sai (Thailand)-Tachilek (Myanmar) and Hekou (PRC)-Lao Cai (Viet Nam) 
border crossings along the North-South Economic Corridor. The MOUs include a time-bound 
action  plan  for  self-executing  articles 4   of  the  CBTA,  commitments  to  expedite  the 
implementation of annexes and protocols following their ratification, and interim measures for 
important procedures, such as the bilateral exchange of traffic rights, until such time that the 
relevant annexes and/or protocols are ratified by GMS governments. Implementation of the 
CBTA began on 30 June 2005 at the Dansavanh-Lao Bao border crossing, will begin by 31 
December 2005 at the Mukdahan-Savannakhet and Aranyaprathet-Poipet border crossings, 
and by 30 June 2006 at the other 4 key border crossings.  
6.  Discussions with GMS officials and other stakeholders during the preparations for the 
CBTA  implementation  at  the  key  border  crossings  during  the  period  September  2004–
September 2005, revealed constraints to the full, immediate, and sustainable implementation of 
the CBTA. The constraints include (i) the need to harmonize the GMS countries’ relevant laws 
and/or regulations with the provisions of the annexes and protocols; (ii) the absence of a critical 
mass of technical capacity among relevant officials at the border crossings; and (iii) the limited 
institutional capacity at the central Government level.  
7.  Major challenges for effective implementation of the CBTA include (i) establishment of 
efficient  management  systems  and  associated  capacity  building;  (ii)  streamlining  and 
harmonization of border control documents; (iii) preparation of revised manuals of operation at 
the border checkpoints and associated training; (iv) establishment of required infrastructure, 
and, in some cases, relocation and/or modification of layouts of border checkpoints as well as 
provision of common control areas to allow single-stop inspection and single-window inspection; 
and (v) mitigation of negative externalities associated with increased cross-border movement. 
Successful implementation of the CBTA at the key border crossings would encourage GMS 
governments to ratify the annexes and protocols and, thus, accelerate full implementation of the 
CBTA subregionwide. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  Overall, the TA is expected to contribute to rapid and sustainable economic growth 
resulting from increased trade and investment. The TA’s expected outcomes are (i) increased 
cross-border trade at border crossings covered by the CBTA; (ii) reduced nonphysical barriers 
to the cross-border movement of goods, vehicles, and people; and (iii) improved capacity for 
sustainable implementation of the CBTA. The expected outputs of the proposed TA are (i)

shortened border crossing clearance times at key border crossings; (ii) finalized arrangements 
for  CBTA  implementation  at  a  second  set  of  border  crossings;  (iii)  recommendations  to 
maximize  benefits  and  address  limitations  of  the  implementation  of  the  CBTA;  and  (iv) 
strengthened National Transport Facilitation Committees (NTFCs).5  The activities of the TA will 
cover all six GMS countries6. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  CBTA  Implementation  at  Key  Border  Crossings. Consistent with the time-bound 
MOUs  for  CBTA  implementation  at  the  seven  key  border  crossings,  the  TA  supports  the 
following measures: (i) harmonizing, simplifying, and rationalizing forms and procedures, and 
preparing manuals for efficient border management consistent with related international (e.g., 
World Customs Organization [WCO]) and regional (e.g., Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
[ASEAN])  agreements,  including  translation  of  forms,  procedures,  and  manuals  into  the 
respective  local  languages;  (ii)  identifying  the  information  and  communication  technology/ 
management information system (ICT/MIS) requirements including the facilitation of pre-arrival 
clearance  procedures,  taking  into  account  ICT/MIS  provided  by  other  external  aid/funding 
agencies; (iii) facilitating the implementation of the single-window system prescribed under the 
ASEAN Customs Cooperation initiatives; (iv) providing limited ICT equipment and software at 
selected border checkpoints, where such are urgently needed to facilitate the establishment of 
an  electronically  transmitted  declaration  system;  (v)  conducting  a  study  on  modern  border 
management systems and recommending its implementation; (vi) conducting location-specific 
training/capacity-building  activities,  including  preparation  of  manuals,  guidelines  and 
procedures,  and  instructional  media;  (vii)  conducting  “before”  and  “after”  border  crossing 
clearance time studies and compiling relevant cross-border statistics to assess the effectiveness 
of facilitation measures; and (viii) monitoring the implementation of, and facilitating compliance 
with, the time-bound arrangements for CBTA implementation and advising the NTFCs and/or 
line agencies of the status of compliance. 
10.  Arrangements for CBTA Implementation at a Second Set of Border Crossings. The 
TA will support the preparation and finalization of arrangements for implementing the CBTA at a 
second set of border crossings. The TA will provide assistance in (i) drafting bilateral time-
bound MOUs for CBTA implementation at each of the second set of border crossings to be 
considered and endorsed by the Ministerial Joint Committee (JC);7 (ii) facilitating meetings to 
negotiate and finalize the MOUs; (iii) identifying and facilitating the provision of requirements for 
establishing  an  effective  border  management  system  and  implementing  single-window 
inspection  and  single-stop  inspection  for  each  border  crossing;  and  (iv)  monitoring  the 
implementation  of  the  MOUs,  and  advising  NTFCs  and/or  line  agencies  on  the  status  of 
compliance.  
11.  Effective and Sustainable Implementation of the CBTA. The TA will assist in (i) 
strengthening  the  existing  institutional  mechanisms  within  each  country  (i.e.,  NTFCs)  and 
among countries (i.e., JC and its subcommittees8); (ii) reviewing the structure of NTFCs, the JC

and its subcommittees, and make recommendations for their operationalization; (iii) examining 
key outstanding issues in the CBTA’s contents and its annexes and protocols; (iv) measuring 
the benefits of improved cross-border transport facilitation, through “before” and “after” studies; 
(v) disseminating information about CBTA implementation to the public and private sectors, 
including at the border areas; and (vi) providing coordination/secretariat support to the JC, its 
subcommittees, and NTFCs.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA will cost about $860,000 equivalent. Detailed cost estimates and the financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. The TA will be financed by the People’s Republic of China Regional 
Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund, funded by the Government of the People’s Republic 
of China in an amount not exceeding $400,000, and by the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) 
TA  funding  program  for  $400,000,  both  administered  by  ADB.  The  participating  GMS 
governments will provide the remaining $60,000 equivalent in kind, in the form of counterpart 
staff as well as logistical support.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Operations Coordination Division of 
ADB’s Mekong Regional Department will take the lead in the TA implementation. NTFCs in the 
six GMS countries will serve as focal points for TA implementation. The TA will be implemented 
over 18 months, from March 2006 to August 2007. 
14.  The TA will be carried out by a team of international and domestic consultants to be 
recruited as individuals in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic  consultants.  Individual 
international  consultants  with  expertise  in  (i)  trade  facilitation,  (ii)  capacity  building  on 
customs/trade facilitation, (iii) transport regulations and international law, and (iv) transport 
facilitation, will be recruited on an intermittent basis during TA implementation.  10 person-
months  of  international  consulting  services  and  42  person-months  of  domestic  consulting 
services will be required. The outline terms of reference are given in Appendix 3. To facilitate 
implementation  at  key  border  crossings,  limited  key  ICT  equipment  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Procurement and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB 
for the procurement of equipment.  On completion of the TA, equipment will be transferred to 
the participating governments. 
15.  The  TA  will  also  support  the  conduct  of  workshops,  studies,  and  capacity  building 
activities related to cross-border transport and trade facilitation. These may be undertaken in 
collaboration with ASEAN, the International Road Transport Union, United Nations Economic 
and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, United Nations Economic Commission for 
Europe,  WCO,  World  Health  Organization,  World  Trade  Organization,  and  other  relevant 
agencies, to draw upon the relevant expertise of these agencies.  
16.  ADB  will  further  develop  its  system  for  monitoring,  updating,  and  disseminating 
information  and  developments  on  cross-border  transport  and  trade  facilitation  activities, 
including monitoring time-bound implementation arrangements. The task will comprise, among 
other things, a systematic collection of cross-border agreements and related materials, and the 
updating of information concerning GMS cross-border transport and trade facilitation on ADB’s 
GMS website (www.adb.org/gms). Reporting on the status of implementation and the outcome

5
of TA activities will be made during GMS Subregional Transport Forum meetings, JC meetings, 
and other relevant regional fora, as appropriate.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty 
Reduction Fund funded by the Government of the People’s Republic of China, and (ii) ADB 
providing  the  balance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $400,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  the 
Implementation of the Greater Mekong Subregion Cross-Border Transport Agreement, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  A team of individual consultants will be engaged to provide the technical services of the 
Project. A total of 10 person-months of international consulting services and 42 person-months 
of  domestic  consulting  services  will  be  required.  The  consultants  will  report  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) task manager for the Project. 
 
2.  The consultants will prepare reports on their tasks and other such reports as required 
and requested by the task manager for the Project. The basic reports will include (i) inception 
report to be submitted within 4 weeks of the start of engagement, (ii) interim report, and (iii) final 
report to be submitted within 4 weeks of completion of engagement.     
 
A.  Transport Facilitation Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
3.  The consultant will have extensive experience in international cross-border transport 
facilitation issues. He or she preferably will have knowledge of the transport facilitation situation 
in  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  countries.  Strong  facilitation  and  intercultural 
communication  skills  and  long-term  working  experience  in  GMS  countries  are  required  to 
effectively perform the assignment. 
 
4.  The responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Examine  the  (a)  structure  of  the  National  Transport  Facilitation  Committee 
(NTFC), and the Ministerial Joint Committee (JC) and its subcommittees, and 
give  recommendations  for  their  operationalization;  (b)  strengthening  of  the 
NTFCs and their respective secretariats; and (c) formulation of effective national 
coordination mechanisms (between and among central Government agencies, 
and  between  central  and  border-level  agencies/  authorities)  for  sustainable 
implementation of the Cross-Border Transport Agreement (CBTA). 
(ii)  Examine  the  implications  of  full  implementation  of  the  CBTA  for  poverty 
reduction, generation of greater trade and investment, and increased mobility of 
people, and recommend mitigating measures to address them. 
(iii)  Review the Study of Transit Charges developed by ADB and United Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, and assess if an 
update on the study is required, and, if necessary, prepare a framework for the 
update.  
(iv)  Recommend initiatives to improve governance at the border crossing points to 
reduce the cost of doing business, taking into account feedback received from 
stakeholders.  
(v)  Formulate  recommendations  to  maximize  the  beneficial  impact  of  full  CBTA 
implementation, and suggest that it be raised at the appropriate national and 
subregional fora including GMS working groups, and JC and its subcommittees 
for appropriate action.

B.  Transport Regulation/Legal Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will have extensive experience in laws and regulations on international 
cross-border  transport  facilitation.  Extensive  working  experience  in  the  GMS  countries  is 
required to effectively perform the assignment. 
 
6.  The responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Review and give recommendations on the feasibility of expanding the CBTA to 
cover other modes of transport, and, if necessary, draft the required amendments 
to the CBTA and/or its annexes or protocols. 
(ii)  Explore the feasibility of formulating a separate agreement for mutual recognition 
of  third-party  motor  vehicle  liability  insurance,  and  other  relevant  insurance 
arrangements, and draft the necessary agreement, if needed, for consideration 
by JC. 
(iii)  Assist the health and sanitary, phytosanitary subcommittee of JC to explore and 
agree on more detailed standards for quarantine and health inspection. 
(iv)  Assist JC in identifying new border crossing points and routes to be included in 
Protocol  1  and,  subsequently,  in  preparing  the  necessary  amendments  to 
Protocol 1.  
(v)  Assist in exploring the expansion of the CBTA to adequately cover required 
facilitation measures to promote other modes of transport. 
 
C.  Trade Facilitation Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
7.  The consultant will have extensive experience and applied knowledge of international 
best practice on trade and transport facilitation, including implementation of modern border 
management system, single-window system, and information and communication technology/ 
management information system (ICT/MIS). Strong facilitation and intercultural communication 
skills and long-term working experience in GMS countries are required to effectively perform the 
assignment.  
 
8.  The responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Review existing forms and procedures on trade and transport facilitation and give 
recommendations to harmonize, simplify, and rationalize them. 
(ii)  Prepare  manuals  for  efficient  border  management  consistent  with  related 
international  (e.g.,  World  Customs  Organization  [WCO])  and  regional  (e.g., 
Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  [ASEAN])  agreements,  including 
translation  of  forms,  procedures,  and  manuals  into  the  respective  local 
languages. 
(iii)  Identify the ICT/MIS requirements related to CBTA implementation taking into 
account ICT/MIS provided by other external aid/funding agencies. 
(iv)  Assist  in  harmonizing  an  electronically  transmitted  declaration  system  (e.g., 
electronic  data  interchange)  for  exchange  of  information  across  border 
checkpoints,  and  to  facilitate  the  implementation  of  pre-arrival  clearance 
procedures. 
(v)  Facilitate the implementation of the single-window system prescribed under the 
ASEAN Customs Cooperation initiatives.

12  Appendix 3   
(vi)  Conduct a study of modern border management and give recommendations on 
how to implement it at remaining border crossings, taking into account feedback 
received from stakeholders. 
(vii)  Identify and facilitate the provision of the requirements for an effective border 
management  system  and  implementation  of  single-window  and  single-stop 
inspection for each border crossing, taking into account implementation of the 
CBTA at the seven key border crossings. 
 
D.  Training and Development Specialist with Customs/Trade Facilitation Expertise 
(international, 3 person-months) 
9.  The  consultant  will  have  extensive  experience  in  (i)  customs/trade  facilitation,  (ii) 
development of training materials; and (iii) conduct of training. 
 
10.  The responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Conduct a detailed assessment of training/capacity-building needs of each of the 
seven key border crossings to support the establishment of an efficient border 
management system, and conduct training based on the outcome of the needs 
assessment. 
(ii)  Prepare  training  materials  for  implementing  the  CBTA,  including  manuals, 
guidelines and procedures, and instructional media. 
(iii)  Conduct  at  the  border  checkpoints  location-specific  training/capacity-building 
activities, possibly in coordination with WCO and/or other relevant organizations, 
in  the  areas  of  risk  management,  use  of  streamlined/harmonized  forms, 
streamlined procedures, use of ICT and an electronically transmitted declaration 
system (e.g., electronic data interchange) for exchange of information across 
border checkpoints. 
(iv)  Assess  training  efficiency  to  determine  the  effectiveness  of  the  training 
conducted.  
 
E.  National  Transport  Facilitation  Specialists/NTFC  Coordination  Assistants 
(domestic, 24 person-months) 
11.  The consultants will be based in the GMS countries and will directly liaise with ADB and 
senior officials of the NTFCs. They should possess extensive knowledge of the operations of 
the NTFC and have good communication skills.   
 
12.  The responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Assist the respective NTFCs in coordinating its activities at national and local 
levels. 
(ii)  Assist  the  international  consultants  in  conducting  their  activities,  including 
preparation  for  national  meetings  and  training  workshops,  and  subregional 
meetings held in the respective home countries. 
(iii)  Monitor the implementation of the time-bound provisions of the memorandum of 
understanding  (MOUs)  for  CBTA  implementation,  provide  timely  feedback  to 
ADB, and, where necessary, facilitate compliance with the various provisions of 
the MOUs.

Appendix 3  13 
F.  Local Transport Facilitation Specialist (domestic, 18 person-months) 
13.  The consultant, who will be based in ADB headquarters, should possess extensive 
knowledge of the CBTA and a good command of the English language. Working experience in 
the GMS countries is required to effectively perform the assignment. 
 
14.  The responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Develop and make operational a monitoring system to identify and disseminate 
updated developments in the finalization, ratification, and implementation of the 
various elements of the CBTA, including the laws and regulations in each GMS 
country that have conformed to the requirements of the CBTA. 
(ii)  Assess  the  effectiveness  of  CBTA  implementation  at  key  border  crossings 
through  the  conduct  of  “before”  and  “after”  studies;  update  as  necessary, 
performance clearance times for border crossing formalities and relevant cross-
border  statistics;  and  the  implementation  of  initiatives  necessary  for  further 
improvements. 
(iii)  Prepare  various  types  of  information  dissemination  media  (e.g.,  brochures, 
updated websites) on the CBTA for use by the potential beneficiaries of cross-
border  transport  facilitation  measures  (e.g.,  transport  operators,  suppliers, 
exporters). 
(iv)  Develop and make operational a monitoring system to identify compliance of 
GMS countries in implementing the CBTA as indicated in the respective MOUs 
for the various pilot border sites, and inform the NTFCs concerned of the status 
of compliance. 
(v)  Assist in preparing, organizing, and convening the meetings of the JC and its 
subcommittees, as well as national and border-level workshops on specific topics 
on cross-border transport facilitation, and ensure the undertaking of follow-up 
actions. 
(vi)  Assist in developing a capacity-building/training plan for officials at the central 
and border/provincial level based on priorities identified in the implementation of 
the CBTA.  
(vii)  Assist in the overall administration of the TA.
